Old wives’ tales have had a bad press down the years. If you drop a fork it means a man is coming to visit. A loaf, once cut, cannot be turned upside down. Brexit means an end to straight bananas (or, indeed, Brexit means Brexit). But just occasionally, the biddies get it right: Cold Feet, warm heart.

It washed back all over our screens, marred only by the kind of breathless media hype that might have embarrassed Adolf at Nuremberg, and reminded us of some oddly hopeful days back in ’97, when Mr Blair had yet to settle on his cabinet and his chosen faces for sad and happy, let alone on his fascinating career path of millionaire war criminal. The theme tune had changed, sadly (few songs speak to our fin de siecle with the redolence of Space’s Female of the Species), but the title typeface was still there in all its spiky, pulsing horror. It was as close as the British got to Friends, with gratifyingly less glucose: Manhattan would never have dared to kill off its Rachel.

All Manc life is here, which is to say all life is here, and I am hooked

And it was by far the finest reheating of leftovers in this season of retro-love. Always well written, treading that tightrope between emotion and sentimentality that Manchester somehow seems always to get right, unlike some of its more shouty neighbours, this return also simply reminded us of the quality of the original cast. Witness how many have since carved out singular successes, or in James Nesbitt’s case, multiple, having proved himself one of the few actors – Olivia Colman’s another, and recently, Tom Hollander – equally adept at smart comedy and at drama that truly punches the kidneys.

The action has obviously moved on to midlife crises, and we can expect much filthy angsting over John Thomson’s all-too-believable depression and Robert Bathurst’s equally credible lack of capacity for self-examination. There’s been a snaring in Singapore by Adam (Nesbitt) of a new wife, who has nothing at all going for her except youth, beauty, wit, money, wisdom, empathy and humour, and who is obviously wrong for him. All Manc life is here, which is to say all life is here, and I am hooked, line and sinker, all over again.

They’ve apparently moved on in Cornwall too, from tin to copper. Damn your eyes, progress!

I’ve no idea why I have such antipathy to Poldark, though it’s more a fug of serene indifference. I should by rights love it – this wild land of seas and wreckers, of Du Maurier, of the Admiral Benbow, of translucent soap, of clotted cream, and the many dangerous dreams lurking within; of jazz fiend Charlie Wycliffe! Yet all I get nowadays is a dull chap in a frock coat riding between the peasants and the cliffs, and getting sadly too close to neither. Perhaps it’s that I made the mistake of starting a Winston Graham book once. More likely it’s that my idea of the flawed hero has always had much less to do with darkly brooding, haughty good looks than with fellow feeling. For every Heathcliff and Poldark, I offer you a Philip Marlowe, a Homer Simpson, an Ernie Bilko… certainly Victoria’s Lord Melbourne, who keeps his kit on and is creaming it in the Sunday night ratings.

So: will Ross get hanged in the newest episode? Or will someone go behind his back, for love, and cut a deal? My money’s on him getting hanged.

Undoubted comedy of the week was Motherland, a terribly truthful exposition of what it means to battle between being the “good” mother – a flawlessly moneyed, pretty, organised and quietly angry Lucy Punch – and the hopeless, exemplified here by Diane Morgan, who lives off frozen food, only gives a forlorn what-the-bugger-now sigh when she severs her finger, and is quietly happy.

Caught in the middle, as I suspect an entire 90% of British mothers are and always have been, is the phenomenal Anna Maxwell Martin as Julia, who makes the one mistake – one! – of lying, once. When asked, by the impossibly kind school to which she ferries with difficulties her two children, whether she had forgotten it was half-term, she opts for a proudly cheerful “No. No?” and so mires herself in a day of tense phone calls, criminal driving, accidental and deliberate snobbery, blood, wine and insane hunger while trying to hold down a job in event management. She’s due later in her hellish week to have Peter Mandelson introduce the Women in Construction awards, which deserves an award of its own. As does the terse “I don’t have to come to the office for a whole day to watch Elaine print out a press release.”

“What time is it now?” she begs Liz (Morgan) as they struggle with their many kids, with prayers for it to be about 4.30pm, or if possible midnight. “Just after midday.” “Fucking HELL.” It’s written by, among others, Sharon Horgan and Graham Linehan, features the most fascinating annoying dad yet written, and is a sure triumph.

Undoubted non-comedy of the week was We the Jury, an alleged piece of humour that actually ran out of ideas before the end of its pilot, which is going some. Did anyone at the BBC actually watch this before it aired? I ask in a spirit of genuine inquiry rather than nastiness, because they’ve just given me Motherland.

Purportedly a half-hour take on jury service, it featured cliched characters and surreal madness; almost never a winning mix. Ivan Goncharov’s novel Oblomov is the only successful example. Written in 1859, it’s only about three thousand times funnier and more interesting, and it was in Russian. Had We the Jury popped up on Radio 4 Extra at half-four in the morning – I’m always awake about then, musing on different lives – I would have had to put on slippers, race to the loo and swallow bleach. Again: did anyone watch this before it aired?

Before the Paralympic opening ceremony – oddly uncaptivating Brazilian music and dance, saved by the disabled pianist João Carlos Martins and (again) the stadium’s digital floor – there was much delight to be had in The Last Leg: Live from Rio, in which Channel 4 trumped in two hours the BBC’s recent 17 or whatever weeks of coverage by being in possession of 1) a tiny budget; 2) a refreshing lack of deference; and 3) a grown-up sense of humour.

Adam Hills, Alex Brooker and Josh Widdecombe had great gags, winning gags, about disability and even about the flight over to Rio: ribald laughter about leg-room, and hand-space in the overhead lockers, and the fact that it was the safest plane that had ever flown – “we had all the shooters”. Clare Balding, who has had a deserved couple of weeks back in Britain to check her bank account – don’t get me wrong, she’s lovely and deserves every tin groat – looked, on the Last Leg sofa, both shocked and delighted. Almost as if she might be allowed, in the next 10 days, to talk not about heroes or legends, but just about humans.

JJ-K from London booked a hire car through the website Rentalcars.com.

“A week was £139.91 and included collision damage waiver, third-party liability and theft protection. However, when I went to collect the car at the airport, the Spanish rental company, Goldcar, told me that this was a ringfenced deposit and that I would have to pay £206 for the hire. The agent gave me an invoice in Spanish. Assuming the total included the deposit, I signed.

“I discovered that the initial £139.91 had not been ringfenced so the total hire charge was £346.32. I called both companies who said that, since I had signed the contract, there was nothing to be done. It turned out that Goldcar had charged me an extra fee for a premium insurance policy, which was not mentioned by the Goldcar agent.”

SM of London has a similar tale. “I am an experienced traveller and have an annual insurance waiver and always refuse ‘supercover’ (or whatever the hire company name their excess).

“The Goldcar agent in Marseille. did not even try to sell me cover as I showed him my annual waiver policy. He said my status as a regular Goldcar hirer meant he did not need a deposit.

“He mentioned the fuel deposit and asked me to sign an electronic pad. When he printed the contract he covered the charges section with a map. He then folded the contract and, just as he passed it to me, thrust a white sheet of paper at me and said I needed to sign.

“I have no idea what the paper actually said. Only later did I discover that €74 had been debited from my account to pay for ‘supercover’ insurance. Goldcar has fobbed me off by saying I got benefit from the ‘supercover’ even though I did not ask for it and they will train their staff better.”

CB of London used Goldcar on a 12-day trip to Italy. “We had paid for a car through Holiday Autos and I took out extra insurance with insurance4carhire.com as a precaution. We were asked to produce the credit card we had used on collection of the car.

“The Goldcar agent never mentioned any extra insurance. However, when we received our credit card statement we found an extra £207.46, including Super Relax Cover.”

RM of Cambridge also found himself paying £60.78 for Super Relax Cover when he hired a Goldcar vehicle in Bologna. “I was told I didn’t have the choice and would have to query it afterwards. I have come to realise that this is a common problem in multiple Goldcar locations.”

Indeed it is. Car hire desks will do their darnedest to flog extra insurance because agents earn a commission.

Goldcar is a notorious offender – so notorious they have been on a PR mission to reassure the public that they are mending their ways. And who are they blaming? Why, customers in their ignorance and the third-party websites through which they book. “Goldcar is aware of the problems,” says a spokesperson. “It is taking measures to educate customers about insurance requirements and the different options. It is also working with intermediaries to improve transparency regarding bookings through their sites.”

Goldcar is hardly telling the full story. These intermediaries may be less than helpful to customers who find themselves paying twice for insurance, but they include in their prices all legally required insurance – collision damage waiver, third party cover and theft protection.

However, Goldcar tells me that it offers the only comprehensive cover on the market, by which it means that its policy covers any excess payable.

Customers who choose not to buy it have to pre-authorise a deposit of at least €950, although it would seem many are not offered this option. And some Goldcar customers report that they are told that unless they buy it, they cannot hire the vehicle.

Again, Goldcar blames third-party websites. It says: “We know it is hard for some intermediaries to control the information displayed as they work with thousands of affiliates, but unfortunately this is their responsibility. We hope this will improve soon.”

Goldcar refuses to refund any of the customers above, stating they all signed the contract agreeing to the extra charges and these were clearly explained. So, the next time you’re at a car hire desk, no matter how late the hour or long the queue, always make sure you understand what you are signing and query any unexpected costs.

Thomas Huxley knew a thing or two about the White Cliffs of Dover. “With vast needles and pinnacles standing out in the sea, sharp and solitary enough to serve as perches for the weary cormorant, [they] confer a wonderful beauty and grandeur,” he wrote in an essay which he simply titled On a Piece of Chalk.

For Huxley, a 19th-century pioneer of evolutionary biology, the white stuff was the perfect substance to demonstrate Earth’s antiquity, made up, as it is, of microscopic, calcified creatures whose powdery remains give us the means to record events and express ourselves artistically. It even gave the country its name, Albion, from albus the Latin for white – a reference to the White Cliffs of Dover.

So where better to sample a new national walking route than the chalk cliffs near Dover? The place that helped define the nation and the site of a recently opened section of the England Coastal Path which, by 2020, will allow outdoor enthusiasts to walk round the 2,790 miles of the nation’s shoreline. This journey will begin at the Scottish border near Bamburgh and take walkers down to Kent and the white cliffs, then along the south coast to Lyme Regis and to Land’s End before heading up to Chepstow – for a brief break to enjoy the 870-mile Wales Coast Path – before rejoining its England Coastal Path at Queensferry and then heading to its northwestern extremity at Gretna. According to Nature England, this will be the longest continuous coastal walking route in the world.

Many of these sections will absorb existing paths that are being tarted up to the standards of a national trail while completely new sections are being constructed. My walk – from the National Trust’s White Cliffs reception centre to Sandwich – would take in both refurbished path and new track and is part of the newly opened Kent section of the coastal path.

And although only a few miles long, the section covers a startlingly diverse and strikingly beautiful chunk of countryside. The White Cliffs, in mid-summer, burst with colour and wildlife: greater knapweed, scabious, lady’s bedstraw, wild mignonette, sea kale, wild marjoram and thyme providing a multicoloured home for marbled white, chalkmill blue, skipper and meadow brown butterflies. Add the odd skylark wheeling overhead and you do indeed have a place of “wonderful beauty and grandeur”.

Yet it soon becomes apparent as we begin our walk that these glories are based on only wafer-thin support. Patches of bare chalk protrude all along the coastal path here and reveal how painfully thin is the soil layer that supports its plants and wildlife.

Nor are the cliffs immutable. Their chalk crumbles at a fairly substantial rate, eroding at an average of a centimetre a year. Every so often a giant chunk collapses into the sea. And for a coastal path this could be bad news. You cannot have the ravages of natures regularly wiping out chunks of your pathway.

Fortunately, the new trail, which was launched in 2007 by the then environment secretary David Miliband, has been established so that Nature England will have the power to rebuild, further inland, any path lost to erosion. In addition, land between the coastal path and shore can now be used for recreation, for example, picnics – a right that was also established when setting up the Coastal Path’s legislation.

With its spectacular plant and insect life, together with the hustle of Dover, the world’s busiest passenger port, behind you and the sight of the Calais coastline to your right, this first section was the most intriguing part of our six-mile walk. It is an exhilarating stroll which, after a couple of miles, takes you to the Fan Bay Deep Shelter, a gun battery cut out of the Kent chalk in 1941 that allowed Britain to shell enemy shipping in the Channel. Recently restored by the Natural Trust, its tunnels, scrawled with 40s graffiti, also provide access to a First World War sound mirror, a giant concrete dish which focused sound waves, rather than radio waves, as a not-very-successful method for detecting incoming planes.

At the South Foreland Lighthouse, you head down steeply to St Margaret’s at Cliffe and head north to Deal and Henry VIII’s Walmer Castle which later provided a home for Pitt the Younger and the Duke of Wellington (who died there). From Deal, the path then follows the coast to Sandwich along a beach made of steep shingle. The pace here is slow and heavy though the place is not without its fascinations, the coast being rich in populations of waders and wildfowl.

Two thirds of the way to Pegwell Bay, the path used to turn east to Sandwich, but now has an extra three miles of route added to it to take walkers round the peninsula at Shellness and down the River Stour to Sandwich, creating a series of new ponds and reserves that are already being colonised by egrets and other wildfowl. It is a stunning little thoroughfare bursting with history and wildlife and as pleasant a few miles as I have ever walked.

Chalk one up to the coastal path.

The news will come as little surprise to weary parents used to wrangling with household budgets: while first-time students, newly empowered with their university loan, feel confident they can manage their money over the year, the reality is often very different.

New research shows that despite their best intentions – nine out of 10 students think they can deal with their finances effectively – most spend it all before the end of term. More worryingly, according to the study by the University of Sheffield and Comparethemarket, one in every nine blow a term’s loan of about £2,700 within two weeks.

With newly attained independence, coupled with the draw of nights out and unexpected bills, many students have to turn to their parents for financial assistance.

Dr Thomas Webb, a social psychologist from the University of Sheffield, says the research shows the gaps which exist between intentions and actions. “They go into the year with good intentions to spread their money out, to make it last, make sure they eat healthily – and they feel confident about doing so. But the research indicates, and a lot of anecdotal information suggests, that students really struggle and get into debt,” he says.

So what can students do to keep their finances in shape throughout the academic year?

Choose the right bank account

With the first term approaching, so do the offers from banks attempting to lure customers in. Free NUS cards, National Express Coachcards and cashback from selected retailers are just some of the sweeteners that come with new accounts.

Both Halifax and HSBC, for example, are offering interest-free overdraft facilities of £3,000. Having an overdraft is, in the absence of another cash buffer, a useful facility in case of unforeseen events. It will, of course, have to be repaid, warns Rachel Springall of Moneyfacts. “There is a huge danger of racking up a large amount of debt and not being able to pay it back when the time comes, which is why students should do everything in their power to use [an overdraft] sparingly and do their best to earn additional income to reduce what they owe,” she says.

The perks that come with accounts should be viewed with scepticism to ensure they are the right fit, she adds: “Some perks are just gimmicks and don’t really give much value to the longevity of the account. Two of the most lucrative incentives to entice students would be a railcard (available from Santander) or a coach card (from NatWest), as these will reduce the cost of travelling across the country for family visits or even mini trips.”

Watch the house deposit

Comparison site Money.co.uk says 40% of students lose an average of £164 when they move out of their private rented accommodation, mostly down to failing to leave it clean and tidy.

Landlords concur, saying that in more than half of cases this is down to properties not being cleaned to a high enough standard. Other students lose out when they don’t sign a detailed inventory on moving in, leaving them open to financial loss if there are disagreements about the contents when they move out.

“Landlords are not the enemy – students must make sure they keep the property in a decent state so that there’s no reason for their landlord to keep their cash. This is money students will be relying on getting back,” says Hannah Maundrell of money.co.uk.

Needlessly losing money from a deposit will be especially frustrating for anyone grappling with spiralling rents, especially in the capital. The cost of halls for a week now stands at £226, according to Shelly Asquith of the National Union of Students. “That is not sustainable for most people,” she says. The union offers advice to students who have problems with their tenancy and advises them to check with students’ unions for a list of credible landlords.

I would definitely warn against going down the path of payday lenders and loan sharks

Shelly Asquith, NUS

Do a trial run

For an 18-year-old who has just moved out of home, dealing with a budget can lead to simple yet unsurprising pitfalls. Webb points out that something as simple as using an oven for an hour can cost many multiples of using the rings on a cooker – a minor cost which can mount up, and one that may not be noticed by a teenager.

“Because these people are managing their finances for the first time, one of the things I think would really help is to give them experience of doing so. With three weeks to go, maybe students who are going to university should be encouraged to go to the supermarket to see how much food costs, and to see the costs of energy bills,” he says, adding that energy monitors be used to accurately show the cost of appliances.

Jody Baker of Comparethemarket says avoiding corner shops and instead going to supermarkets can also result in useful savings, while student discounts should be pursued with rigour.

Get the right cover

It is estimated that the average student has possessions worth almost £3,400 when phones, laptops and printers are added up alongside their other belongings. Insurer Endsleigh, which was created to service the student market, warns that relying on family home insurance may not give the right level of cover. “Deciding what to take from home to university can be daunting – favourite possessions along with the right kit can amount to a lot of stuff that’s worth a lot of money,” says Sara Newell from the insurer. “It is vital that students starting university feel safe in their accommodation, and secure in the knowledge that their valuable items are protected.”.

Break it up and budget

Budgeting for outgoings should be a given when trying to ensure there is money left at the end of the term – not always easy when student loan instalments typically come in three stages throughout the year. Although there is a campaign to get this changed to a monthly payment, students have been advised to do it themselves in the meantime. “Move your lump sum into another account and send yourself a standing order each week or month,” says Baker.

What to do if trouble strikes

The NUS says half of students have difficulties in paying their rent. Some succumb to payday lenders, which Asquith says aggressively target students in the period before their next loan cheque arrives, when they can be in financial peril. Some students succumb and can then be subject to the aggressive interest fees which are attached to this type of borrowing.

“I would definitely warn against going down the path of payday lenders and loan sharks. There are a significant proportion of students, based on our own data, who are accessing these loans and it is obviously very high risk, with a high level of interest,” Asquith says.

In case they do find themselves in financial difficulties, students are advised to approach advisors at their university and see what financial support may be available.

“Often there are things like bursaries and emergency loans that you can access if you need to put a deposit down on something,” Asquith says.

‘ALL OF US HAVE MONEY WORRIES’

For Daizy Dervishali and her friends, money worries are an ongoing subject. The 20-year-old is about to enter her final year at Ravensbourne in London, and estimates that accommodation and bills will run to £900 a month.

Her loan of £8,100 will come up short, so Dervishali will cover the rest with a job and an iron discipline towards budgeting, withdrawing just what she will spend on a night out and trying to prevent a repeat of a situation last year where small withdrawals of £30 later added up to a problem at the end of the year.

“I think every student has money worries. All of my friends that are at uni stopped going out at the end of last year because they couldn’t afford it,” she says. “The majority of the time I don’t see them because they’ve all got jobs.”

While she is confident she will be able to keep her budget on track for her final year, she is less sure of when she will be able to repay her student loans - possibly not until she is in her mid- to late-30s - well past 2030.

The “will-they-won’t-they” waltz continues, as our tiny heroine cold-shoulders her future husband (“Albert is such a prig, I’d rather marry Robert Peel.” Lord Melbourne: “I wonder what Lady Peel would say to that.”), although pulses race in the woods, where her quietly smouldering cousin proves a dab hand with an injured Dash. Elsewhere, the Queen learns about these new-fangled postage stamps: “So everyone who wants to send a letter will have to lick my face?” Ali Catterall

First Day at Big School

7pm, Channel 5
Educating Yorkshire meets The Secret Life Of 4 Year Olds in this appropriately timed new documentary. The film follows children as they strike up friendships, establish a pecking order and attempt to out-count each other to 100. Tears and tantrums are inevitable when there are cameras in your face and you’re desperate for a nap, but the kids’ one-liners make this show as heartwarming as its predecessors. Grace Rahman

Scotland and the Battle for Britain

8pm, BBC2
The implications of Brexit for a country determined to stay in the EU mean that Scotland’s role in UK politics hasn’t carried so much weight in decades. Hence this two-part programme presented by Andrew Marr, which begins by examining the shift in power that has occurred since the 1950s, with the Unionists giving way to Labour, who have ceded to the SNP. Informative and handsomely presented, with contributions from Nicola Sturgeon and Tony Blair. David Stubbs

Poldark

9pm, BBC1
The pulpy, never desperately subtle, melodrama continues with Aidan Turner’s Ross facing the noose at Bodmin Assizes. An earlier case suggests a hanging judge and there’s a hint of revolutionary fervour abroad in Cornwall that would appear to make leniency unlikely. To make matters worse, Demelza is trying to butter up the judge and turning him against her beloved in the process. Is Ross going to swing? At this early stage in the series, don’t expect the unexpected. Phil Harrison

Jimmy Carr and the Science of Laughter: A Horizon Special

9pm, BBC2
Snobs balk at celeb-fronted science but Jimmy Carr delivers a textbook Horizon here, in the sense that it’s half an hour of solid info in an hour-long slot. Carr uses a studio audience, boffins and his own skills to explore why and how humans laugh, in a programme that elaborately demonstrates simple facts. It does improve late on when it’s just the experts explaining stuff, including a new theory of what comedy is. Jack Seale

World of the Wild

6pm, Nat Geo Wild
A double bill of sumptuous nature programming looking at how animals develop and survive as they face threats from environmental changes. First up are wetlands, with a look at the creatures that live in swamps, marshes and lagoons, from birds to feisty saltwater crocodiles. At 6.30pm, it’s deserts, exploring the lives of the surprisingly diverse wildlife that can survive in the kind of heat that would have humans reaching for the factor 50. Hannah Verdier

Suits

10pm, Dave
This machine-tooled procedural about sharply attired corporate lawyers in New York took a sharp turn in its sixth season, chucking co-lead Mike Ross – a charismatic associate with a photographic memory but no actual law degree – in jail. After eight episodes of frantic legal scrambling and dicey backroom deals, it looks as if Mike is getting out. But his inmate nemesis Gallo (who looks a lot like Father Phil from The Sopranos) is not happy about it. Graeme Virtue

Film choices

Out of Sight
(Steven Soderbergh, 1998), 10.15pm, ITV3
This hip and witty thriller brought indie star Soderbergh storming into the mainstream. Scriptwriter Scott “Get Shorty” Frank plots an intricate, expert path through Elmore Leonard’s twisty novel, and hangs on to the master’s snappy dialogue. Meanwhile, George Clooney’s bank robber and Jennifer Lopez’s federal marshal fizz with odd-couple chemistry. Paul Howlett

Edge of Darkness
(Martin Campbell, 2010), 11.45pm, BBC1
This remake of the BBC’s excellent 1985 conspiracy thriller stars Mel Gibson as detective Thomas Craven, investigating the shocking murder of his activist daughter (Bojana Novakovic) and following a tangled trail through corporate coverup and political collusion. It lacks the complexity and abiding sense of menace of the TV series but it’s still a powerfully gripping movie with big action scenes. PH

Point Blank
(Fred Cavayé, 2010), 12 midnight, BBC2
Like Cavayé’s Anything For Her, this is a story about an apparently ordinary man proving to be extremely resourceful in exceptional (criminal) circumstances. Here, the hero is Gilles Lellouche’s hospital worker who is forced to help gangsters when they threaten his pregnant wife. A terrific flight across Paris ensues; Cavayé is really very good at this stuff. PH

Price: £28,380
Top speed: 155mph
0-62mph: 5.8 seconds
CO2: 149g/km
MPG: 43.5

This is the most powerful road-going Seat ever built. It’s the embodiment of the Spanish carmaker’s 20-year quest to create a usable family saloon that goes like the absolute clappers; a car that’s as easy to use as a pair of slippers one minute, as resolute as a sprinter’s spikes the next. It has a gurgling turbocharged petrol engine that generates 290bhp (that’s a lot) and whips you to a top speed of 155mph, slamming you to 62mph in just under 6 seconds. It’s a car for which adjectives like “blistering”, “balls-out” and “hooning” were created. So why am I stuck axle-deep in a muddy field in Wiltshire’s Chalke Valley? Top speed about 2mph…

Well, clearly, the best way to test a high-performance saloon is to take your mother-in-law to a charming history festival where the car park is doing its best impression of a First World War battlefield. And I have to say the race-tuned Seat put in a memorable performance. I blipped the throttle and its low-pro race wheels sent showers of gloopy mud over the volunteers pushing us out.

Back on the tarmac the Leon quickly settles down to doing what it does best. Seat’s engineers have fiddled about beneath the bonnet so that performance from the engine (it’s the same 2-litre used in Golf’s GTi) has been maxed out. This means that with a flick of a rubbery button you can snap out of everyday mode and opt for dynamic handling and white-knuckle acceleration. It certainly spices up your trip to the supermarket.

Seat’s sports division takes its name from Cup and Racing. The “Cupra” programme was launched in 1996 after the brand won the World Rally Championship. The word Cupra is also, apparently, the name of a fertility goddess worshipped by the ancient Etruscans. My mother-in-law was more impressed by this historical reference than my talk of its tweaked 2-litre boy-racer power plant.

The Leon Cupra is a wonder to drive – the engine may have been beefed up but it hasn’t been overwrought. It’s not some twitchy stallion. Squeeze the throttle and the power grows smoothly in a wonderful and satisfying crescendo. Chassis control and progressive steering add to the pleasure.

All good then? Yes, except for one thing: the price. It’s jarringly expensive. The list price is £28,380, but add some metallic paint and a decent sound system and you soon soar past 30 grand. I spend a lot of time marvelling at how much disposable income other people seem to have, but it seems wildly indulgent to blow that much on a saloon racer – no matter how good it is in the mud.

Dame Sarah Storey, who knows a thing or two about track cycling, did say that Kadeena Cox was going to smash her rivals out of the Velodrome in the C4-5 500m time trial. Tempting though it was to suspect that Storey was trying to lure her younger team-mate into a false sense of security, her prediction was spot on. By the end of Cox’s ride, it was worth a check to see if there were any bike-shaped holes in the roof of this boisterous, sweaty arena.

Over at the Olympic Stadium, Hannah Cockroft was making a successful defence of her T34 100m title, a victory that was impossible to greet with anything other than a shrug of the shoulders. Cockroft’s superiority in wheelchair racing meant that her third Paralympic gold was never in doubt.

Related: Paralympic debut for triathlon sees Britain going for gold in Rio

It could not match the tension in the velodrome, where Cox survived the stress of waiting until the final ride before becoming the first British Paralympian to win medals in two sports in the same Games since Isabel Newstead in 1988. Her second racked up the track team’s sixth gold from these Games.

Cox, who claimed bronze in the T38 100m on Friday night, must have felt jittery by the time she got on her bike. Storey, who became the most successful British female Paralympian of all time when she won her 12th gold on Thursday, was in third place after clocking a time of 37.068sec. China’s Jianping Ruan had moved above the defending champion with a Paralympic C4 record of 36.557. Jufang Zhou, a Chinese C5 rider, was therefore looking at gold after setting a world record of 36.004.

The stakes could not have been higher. The target looked unreachable. It seemed that Cox had a mountain to climb; she had run a 100m race the night before. Later she would admit to being physically and mentally exhausted.

In keeping with Storey’s prediction, however, Cox did not just beat Zhou’s time, she smashed it. Cox, a 25-year-old from Leeds who was a budding able-bodied sprinter before she was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis following a stroke two years ago, looked shaky at the start line. She finished in 34.598sec.

There were doubts that she could pull it off. She only took up professional cycling 18 months ago and divides her training time between Leeds and Manchester. Her coaches have told her to pick one sport in the past, but she wants it all. She was moved into a tougher classification in athletics but still finished third in the 100m. “I said two years ago in my hospital bed I would go to Rio and now I have done that,” Cox said. “I have showed that whatever the setbacks in life you can do it. I never expected this.”

There could be more to come. Cox is in the 400m and 4x100m relay in the athletics and the road race in the cycling. Her stunning ride meant that Storey finished outside the medal places in Paralympic track cycling for the first time since 2008.

Cockroft, who claimed Britain’s fifth gold in athletics, is the Storey of wheelchair racing. The 24-year-old from Halifax was too fast for her team-mate, Kare Adenegan, who was delighted with her silver medal.

Adenegan, a 15-year-old from Coventry, ended Cockroft’s seven-year unbeaten run by pipping her in the 400m in London last year. Not this time. Cockroft was unstoppable, managing a Paralympic record of 17.42sec, while Adenegan clocked a personal best of 18.29sec. “Kare has never come as close to me before in the 100m,” Cockroft said. “She pushed a brilliant race.”

Cockroft’s victory was Britain’s third gold on day three in Rio. There was no reason for Megan Giglia to be disappointed after she missed out on a second cycling medal in the C1-3 500m time trial, while Louis “Rocket” Rolfe finished fifth in the men’s C1-3 1km time trial despite briefly rising to second place in the standings. China’s Li Zhangyu won gold with a world record time of 1min 6.678sec.

Competing in her first Paralympics, Giglia won Britain’s first gold in Rio on Thursday, dominating the 3km individual pursuit. She was on her way to collecting her second gold after posting a world record time of 41.252sec but was pushed into fifth place. Alyda Norbuis of the Netherlands won gold with a C2 world record time of 36.908sec.

In the swimming, Britain’s Ellie Robinson, the 15-year-old who won gold in the S6 50m butterfly, finished fourth in the S6 50m freestyle final. Robinson was inspired by watching Ellie Simmonds win gold in London four years go. They were in the pool together last night. But Simmonds finished sixth.

Alice Tai, a 17-year-old swimmer from New Milton, finished third in the S10 100m backstroke to claim her first Paralympic medal.
